awd_abstract_narration:
The Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) has detected gravitational waves (GWs) --ripples in space and time-- that were emitted by the collision of two black holes billions of light-years from Earth.  The rate and accuracy of these detections will improve as LIGO is upgraded. By comparing the detected waves with detailed predictions of the waves, scientists can measure properties (locations, masses, spins) of the black holes and learn about how they might have formed and how they warp space and time as they collide.  The predictions are made using the equations of General Relativity, written down by Einstein in 1915 but unsolvable (for colliding black holes) until about 2005 with the development of advanced methods and powerful supercomputers. This project supports theoretical work designed to underpin and improve LIGO's ability to extract from observed GWs the rich information that the waves carry.  This includes the improvement and use of the Spectral Einstein Code (SpEC), currently the most accurate computer code for solving Einstein's equations for black hole binaries. SpEC will be used to carry out numerical solutions of black-hole collisions for the purpose of analyzing LIGO data.  In addition, a new computer code SpECTRE will be developed; this is a next-generation upgrade of SpEC designed for new upcoming computer architectures and accuracies beyond those of current codes. SpECTRE will be used to predict gravitational waveforms from two colliding neutron stars and from a black hole colliding with a neutron star.  Gravitational waves from neutron-star collisions are expected to be observed by LIGO, and can teach scientists about how matter behaves at ultra-high densities.  This program will also serve as a training ground for young physicists and astrophysicists. The new code SpECTRE and its output will be publicly released.  Group members will reach out to the general public through lectures, interactive web pages, and YouTube videos.

By combining analytical techniques and numerical simulations with SpEC: (i) Gravitational-wave signals for black-hole binaries will be generated for use in LIGO data analysis, will be used to calibrate analytic models, and will be used to produce numerical surrogate models that can evaluate a single waveform in milliseconds while retaining the accuracy of full numerical simulations; and (ii) the dynamical behavior of highly curved spacetime will be explored via analytic, perturbative, and numerical approaches. The next-generation open-source code SpECTRE will be developed for numerical relativity simulations with matter and radiation. SpECTRE uses Discontinuous Galerkin finite element methods. It is designed for high accuracy and high scalability on current and future supercomputers by following a novel task-based parallelization paradigm. SpECTRE's initial version already implements general-relativistic magnetohydrodynamics. It will be upgraded to handle the dynamical space  times of neutron star-neutron star and black hole-neutron star mergers, including nuclear-theory based hot equations of state and neutrinos. SpECTRE will be applied to studies of BH and accretion disk formation to understand dynamics and GW emission. It will be used for high-accuracy ultra-long neutron star inspiral simulations to predict GW signals and help LIGO constrain the nuclear equation of state.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

The primary scientific objective of this program, carried out at the California Institute of Technology, was to theoretically underpin and improve LIGO's ability to extract from observed GWs the rich information that the waves carry.  We have made number of contributions, including:

(1) We have used our numerical-relativity (NR) code SpEC to produce a public catalog of over 2000 high-accuracy binary black-hole (BBH) simulations. This catalog is used by LIGO and by researchers who develop fast analytic waveform models, and has also been used for other purposes unrelated to LIGO.

(2) We have further developed and improved NR "surrogate models": fast formulas for computing BBH waveforms with almost the same accuracy as NR, but that can run in milliseconds instead of weeks/months. Building these fast formulas requires running hundreds of NR simulations ahead of time.  One of our surrogate models now treats fully precessing binaries with mass ratios up to 4 and arbitrary spin directions, and includes both the waveform and the properties of the final black hole.  Another of our surrogate models does not cover precession, but is valid for the entire LIGO frequency band for total binary masses as low as 2.25 solar masses. Our surrogate models are incorporated into LIGO software.  

(3) We have simulated BBHs in beyond-Einstein theories of gravitation, and we have estimated the signal-to-noise necessary for LIGO measurements to distinguish these theories from general relativity.  We have also estimated the effects of these beyond-Einstein theories on black hole shadows as observed by the Event Horizon Telescope.

(4) We have improved methods and techniques in NR; in particular, we have studied better methods of choosing coordinates, and implemented a much-improved "Cauchy Characteristic Extraction" method for accurately computing gravitational waveforms from simulations. We have developed methods for computing "memory" effects in NR waveforms. We have accelerated the development of our next-generation code SpECTRE, which is designed to take advantage of upcoming massively parallel compute clusters.

(5) We have applied SpEC to simulations of binary neutron stars (NSNS) and collisions of a black hole and a neutron star (BHNS). We have improved our treatment of neutrinos.  We have studied the remnant of a merger, including ejected material, and emitted neutrinos, and we have investigated the remnant accretion disk, including magnetic fields and finite-temperature equations of state.

(6) We have pursued analytic investigations of dynamical tides that can be raised on a neutron star during NSNS coalescense, and the prospect of using these tidal effects to measure properties of neutron stars from gravitational wave observations.

(7) We have studied how gravitational-wave measurements can be used to probe scenarios such as triple systems, and to measure properties of a supermassive black hole by its perturbations on the signal from a nearby stellar-mass BBH.

(8) We have studied the possibility of exotic compact objects that might masquerade as black holes, and how to identify such objects if they exist.

(9) We have investigated the science case for a proposed future space-based gravitational-wave detector, and the possibility of using space-based measurements to tune and optimize ground-based detectors for imminent events.

Broader impacts:

This research program served as a training ground for young scientists, by teaching them a wide variety of research techniques, ranging from astrophysical phenomenology of GW sources and the study of astrophysical systems by analytic techniques and 3+1-dimensional numerical simulations.  Roughly 6 graduate students and 3 postdocs were trained broadly because of this project, and some are now in faculty positions.  Research results were disseminated via the internet (the SXS website, http://www.black-holes.org, and youtube videos on https://youtube.com/SXSCollaboration), outreach lectures by group members, and interactions with undergraduates and community college students.
